title: Systems Thinking
text:
The City = Complex Systems

A city is decomposable into semi-predictable parts.
It is a dynamic process of organized complexity.
The Smart City Paradox:

We have new technical capabilities (Big Data, sensors, AI).
But they rely on modelling techniques devised decades ago to solve social problems.




The city is the ultimate complex system.
â€œSmartâ€ doesnâ€™t mean â€œNew.â€ Many of the algorithms we use today were born in the 1960s and 70s to address social housing, transport equity, and urban decay. The technology has caught up to the theory, but the focus remains social.

title: Systems Thinking
text:
Complexity alive




To a computer or a traditional top-down planner, this looks like total disorder. But it isnâ€™t. It is a highly efficient, self-organizing system where thousands of individual decisions create a functional flow. This is the â€˜organized complexityâ€™ Jane Jacobs spoke aboutâ€”and it is exactly what we struggle to represent in a static model.â€

What the Smart City is NOT

It is not a crystal ball for perfect prediction.
It is not a digital twin that is the reality.
The Map is not the Territory:

Models are simplified representations.
In a complex system, â€œTotal Controlâ€ is an illusion.
We model to understand potentiality, not to dictate outcomes.




models are fallible.

â€œThe Answer,â€ they are misrepresenting what a model is. Itâ€™s a tool for exploration, not a decree.

title: Systems Thinking
text:
The Science of Cities



â€œâ€¦cities must now be looked at as constellations of interactions, communications, relations, flows, and networks rather â€¦ than locations [â€¦] location is, in effect, a synthesis of interactions.â€
â€” Michael Batty, 2013





Use this to transition into the modeling heuristics. If location is just a â€œsynthesis of interactions,â€ then to model a city, we shouldnâ€™t just map where things are (static), but how things move and relate (dynamic). This justifies why we look at things like Networks and Agent-Based models.

title: Systems Thinking
text:
Organized Complexity
Jane Jacobs


Cities are not:

Problems of Simplicity
Problems of Disorganized Complexity (millions of random variables).


They are problems of Organized Complexity:

A huge number of factors which are interrelated into an organic whole.



Jane Jacobs (1961) borrowed this term from Warren Weaver. Explain the difference: - Simplicity: A falling stone (gravity). - Disorganized: A gas (billions of atoms behaving randomly). - Organized: A city or a living cell. Everything depends on everything else. If you change the park (social), you change the crime rate (social), which changes the property value (economic), which changes the transport needs (technical).

title: Systems Thinking
text:
The Interconnection of Parts

â€œThe city is not a work of artâ€¦ the city is a process.â€ â€“ J.Jacobs


It is a Bottom-Up system.
Small, local interactions \(\rightarrow\) Large, global patterns.


Highlight that both Jane Jacobs and Christopher Alexander saw the â€œinterconnection of partsâ€ as the central issue. For the studentsâ€™ projects: Tell them that when they model a â€œSmart Cityâ€ intervention, they arenâ€™t just adding a â€œpartâ€ to a machine; they are intervening in a â€œliving processâ€ that will react in unpredictable ways.

title: Systems Thinking
text:
Complexity Science
The Reductionist Shortcut:

A mental habit of breaking the city into isolated â€œpartsâ€ to make it easier to manage.

The Complexity Reality:

Science not of the â€œatomsâ€ (buildings, roads, people), but of the connections between them.


Cross-Scale Interactions

Single street-level decisions ripples up to the metropolitan scale.



â€œReductionism is a form of mental lazy gymnastics. Our brains are hardwired to simplify: we see a â€˜housing problemâ€™ or a â€˜transport problemâ€™ as separate buckets because itâ€™s cognitively cheaper to process.â€ - But cities donâ€™t work in buckets. Complexity science is about the â€˜glueâ€™â€”the flows and communications that Michael Batty mentioned. - Emphasize that we arenâ€™t studying the â€˜atomsâ€™ (the physical objects) but the â€˜chemistryâ€™ (how they react when they touch). This is why the â€˜Brainâ€™ of the city needs to be a systems-thinking brain, not just a spreadsheet of isolated parts.

title: Systems Thinking
text:
Systems


Complex

Adaptive relationships.
Emergent outcomes.
More than the sum of its parts.


Complicated

Fixed relationships.
Predictable outcomes.
The sum of its parts.


   

A Boeing 747 is complicated; itâ€™s difficult to understand, but itâ€™s reliable and linear. A city is complex; it is alive. In a complicated system, if you remove a part, you just have a broken machine. In a complex system, if you remove a part, the system adapts or collapses entirely.

title: Systems Thinking
text:
1. The Spatial Dimension

The Logic of â€œWhereâ€: Focuses on geometry, distance, and density.
Key Question: How does the physical arrangement of assets (buildings, parks, roads) determine urban performance?
Core Concept: Social Physics. Just like gravity, â€œmassâ€ (high-density jobs or housing) exerts a pull on the surrounding area.


Spatial logic is the traditional bread and butter of planning. Itâ€™s about the map. It assumes that proximity equals interaction.

title: Systems Thinking
text:
2. The Relational Dimension

The Logic of â€œConnectionâ€: Focuses on topology and network hierarchy.
Key Question: How is the city â€œwiredâ€? Is it about how far you are in meters, or how many turns you are from the main network?
Core Concept: Graph Theory. The city as nodes and edges.

title: Systems Thinking
text:
3. The Temporal Dimension

The Logic of â€œWhenâ€: Focuses on change, evolution, and path dependency.
Key Question: How did the city get here, and how fast is it changing?
Core Concept: Dynamics. Recognizing that an urban intervention today might take 10 years to show its true impact (delays).

title: Systems Thinking
text:
4. The Systemic Dimension

The Logic of â€œWhyâ€: Focuses on causality and interdependencies.
Key Question: What are the unintended consequences? If we improve transport, does it inadvertently raise rents and displace the people it was meant to help?
Core Concept: Feedback Loops. Circular causality where an output of a system becomes an input for the next cycle.

Land-Use Transport
LUTI




Primary Dimensions:


Spatial (High) + Relational (Medium)






The Anatomy

Land-Use data
Transport


The Engine
Uses gravity equations to find a state of â€œEquilibriumâ€ between where people live, where they work, and how they travel.



LUTI is the â€œStrategic Plannerâ€™sâ€ model.
It assumes the city seeks a balance. If you reduce travel time to the city center, the â€˜brainâ€™ of this model calculates that property values will rise.
It is great for long-term infrastructure but often misses â€œsuddenâ€ social shifts.
Input/Output: Zonal data (population/jobs) Predicted traffic flows and land-use shifts.

text:
Land-Use Transport

eg. Predicting the impact of a new Metro line on residential density in a suburban area.



Pros
Excellent for long-term strategic planning and infrastructure â€œstress testing.â€

Cons
Highly aggregate (treats people as masses) and mostly static (ignores the â€œchaosâ€ of daily life).





What it lacks


Temporal and Systemic feedback. It assumes a city is a puzzle that can be â€œsolvedâ€ into a perfect balance.

title: Systems Thinking
text:
Network Models

eg. Redesigning a town center to increase footfall for local shops by improving topological connectivity.



Pros
Very high correlation with real-world human movement; requires minimal data (just the map).

Cons
Can be â€œblindâ€ to land use. It might predict high movement on a street that is topologically central but has no reason for people to go there.





What it lacks


Systemic â€œAttractors.â€ It prioritizes the shape of the container over the content inside it.

title: Systems Thinking
text:
System Dynamics
SD eg. The Forrester Model




Primary Dimensions:


Temporal (High) + Relational (High)






The Anatomy

Stocks (Accumulations)
Flows (Rates of change)
Feedback Loops


The Engine
Differential Equations. It simulates how quantities (stocks) change over time based on rates of change (e.g., construction rate).



This is the â€œMacroâ€ view or the â€œPolicy-makerâ€™sâ€ brain.
It originates from Jay Forresterâ€™s work at MIT in the 1960s.
Unlike LUTI, it doesnâ€™t care where a specific building is; it cares about the total number of buildings and how fast they are being built or decaying.
Itâ€™s designed to find â€œcounter-intuitiveâ€ results where obvious social policies might fail.

title: Systems Thinking
text:
System Dynamics

eg. Modeling how a city-wide â€œAir Quality Zoneâ€ affects car ownership and public health over two decades.



Pros
Powerful for identifying â€œPolicy Resistanceâ€ and understanding long-term, non-linear consequences.

Cons
â€œSpatially Blindâ€â€”it treats the entire city (or zone) as a single bucket, ignoring internal geography.





What it lacks


Spatial Granularity. It assumes a city is a â€œwell-mixedâ€ vat of variables rather than a physical place with unique neighborhoods.






Mention the â€œUrban Decayâ€ example from the Forrester paper.
Explain that SD is about the â€œPlumbingâ€ of the city. If you pour a policy in one end, where does it leak out?
It is the primary tool for recognizing the â€œSystem Archetypesâ€ (like Fixes that Fail) that we will discuss in the workshop.

title: Systems Thinking
text:
Agent-Based Models
ABM & Celullar Automata (CA)




Primary Dimensions:


Spatial (High) + Systemic (High) + Temporal (Medium).






The Anatomy

Agents: (People, vehicles, firms) with unique attributes.
Rules: Simple â€œIf/Thenâ€ behaviors.
Environment: The grid or network they inhabit.


The Engine
Bottom-up Micro-simulation. Simple rules from the agents give rise to â€œemergentâ€ states from thousands of these local interactions.


Visit https://softologyblog.wordpress.com/category/agent-based-modeling/
https://www.washingtonpost.com/graphics/2020/world/corona-simulator/
It rejects the idea of â€œEquilibrium.â€ Instead, it looks for â€œEmergenceâ€â€”how simple individual rules lead to complex, collective patterns.
Famous example: Thomas Schelling showed that even if individuals have a very mild preference for neighbors like themselves, the entire city will eventually become highly segregated. The â€œBrainâ€ here is decentralized.

title: Systems Thinking
text:
Agent-Based Models

_eg. Simulating pedestrian evacuation patterns in a high-density transit hub to identify â€œbottlenecksâ€ that traditional flow models miss.



Pros
Captures â€œEmergent Phenomenaâ€ and diversity; allows for the modeling of irrational or â€œhumanâ€ behaviors.

Cons
Computationally expensive; very difficult to â€œvalidateâ€ because small changes in rules can lead to wildly different outcomes.





What it lacks


Predictive Certainty. Because it is stochastic (probabilistic), it gives you a range of â€œpossible futuresâ€ rather than a single definitive answer.





Emphasize that ABM is the ultimate tool for â€œComplexityâ€ as Jane Jacobs described it.
It treats the city as a living laboratory.
For their projects: If they are looking at social equity or behavior change (like recycling habits or walking vs.Â driving), this is the logic they are implicitly using.

title: Systems Thinking
text:
The â€œWickedâ€ Problem

Urban challenges are not puzzles (with one right answer).
They are Wicked Problems:

They are interconnected: solving one creates another.
They have no â€œstopping ruleâ€ or perfect solution.
They are better or worse, not right or wrong.



Refer to Rittel and Webberâ€™s definition 1973. Explain that in a smart city context, we often try to â€œoptimizeâ€ things. But a city isnâ€™t a machine to be optimized; itâ€™s a wicked problem to be managed. For their assignments: help them see that their chosen problem (e.g., housing or pollution) is â€œwickedâ€ because itâ€™s tied to a dozen other factors.
Key Characteristics of Wicked Problems:

No definitive formulation: The problem itself is hard to define.
No â€œstopping ruleâ€: Thereâ€™s no clear point at which you know itâ€™s solved.
Solutions arenâ€™t true/false: They are only â€œgoodâ€ or â€œbad,â€ not objectively correct.
Irreversible consequences: Every attempt to solve it has lasting impacts, making â€œtrials countâ€.
Interconnectedness: Solving one part often creates or reveals other problems.

title: Systems Thinking
text:
System Archetypes

Balancing & LimitsUnintended FeedbackResource & Power Loops



Limits to Growth: A tech-hub grows fast until housing prices drive out the talent, hitting a plateau.
Eroding Goals: Reducing environmental targets because the current infrastructure â€œcannot handleâ€ the cost of meeting them.
Growth and Underinvestment: Demand for public transit grows, but the city delays purchasing new trains, leading to a collapse in service quality.




Fixes that Fail: Widening a road to fix traffic leads to â€œinduced demand,â€ creating more traffic than before.
Shifting the Burden: Using temporary â€œband-aidâ€ repairs on aging water pipes instead of replacing the fundamental infrastructure.
Escalation: Two neighboring districts compete to offer the lowest taxes to attract firms, eventually bankrupting their own public services.




Tragedy of the Commons: Unregulated groundwater extraction by individual buildings leading to the sinking of the entire cityâ€™s foundation.
Success to the Successful: High-income neighborhoods receive the best schools, which increases property values and further concentrates educational funding there.
Accidental Adversaries: A transit agency and a housing department both try to optimize their own KPIs, but end up blocking each otherâ€™s long-term goals.






Learning to recognize â€œThe Classicsâ€ of urban failure.
Remind students that these are diagnostic tools.
They donâ€™t describe a specific problem, but a family of problems.
Use these tabs to ask the groups: â€œWhich of these â€˜Classicsâ€™ best describes the wicked problem you are mapping today?â€.

title: Interview questions
text:
Iâ€™ve spent the last decade at the intersection of data science and the built environment. Early on, I realized that while infrastructure is static, human behavior is dynamic. This led me to the Space Syntax approachâ€”essentially using data-driven, graph-based analysis to understand multi-scale networks. It allowed me to bridge the gap between rigorous academic theory and the practical realities of urban consultancy.
In terms of technical scale, my experience is quite broad. Iâ€™ve managed everything from high-frequency IoT sensor data for real-time indoor movement to architecting the tracking of entire city bus networks modelling scenarios. Iâ€™ve applied these insights to everything from local â€˜urban acupunctureâ€™ strategies to large-scale masterplans, always focusing on how we can use data to measure social benefits. My work has taken me across the globeâ€”from Colombia to Australia, London, and now Madridâ€”which has given me a deep appreciation for the cultural nuances required to work effectivily with multinational teams.
Inevitably, working on European urban development leads you to the Net-Zero agenda. Most recently, in 2024, I led a team of eight researchers at the Norman Foster Institute to develop the Climate Action Plan for Athens. This was a major milestone where we had to harmonize environmental data,set plans for reaching carbon emission targets, and greening strategies into a compliant, actionable policy framework.
This work led me to what I call my â€˜professional obsessionâ€™: the link between environmental quality and human health outcomes. Iâ€™ve realized that the environmentâ€”whether itâ€™s air quality, climate resilience, or the built landscapeâ€”is the primary driver of health inequalities. Over the last year, Iâ€™ve been focusing on quantifying these links, moving from spectral analysis of country-wide information to advising on transport initiatives that prioritize health outcomes. I want to move beyond just â€˜collecting dataâ€™ to reducing the environmental inequalities that impact peopleâ€™s lives.
That brings me here. I see this role at the EEA as the ideal next frontier. Itâ€™s the one place where I can combine data at scale, health implications, and European policy. Iâ€™ve spent my career â€˜forcingâ€™ these elements to meet, and Iâ€™m eager to bring that integrated perspective to the Agencyâ€™s monitoring and evidence-gathering mission.



There are three primary reasons why I am sitting here today, ranging from the Agencyâ€™s unique mandate to the urgency of our current environmental timeline.

The Unique Intersection of Science and Policy First, from an institutional perspective, the EEA is unparalleled. There is truly no other organization in the world where high-level science, legislative policy, and ground-level implementation meet with such a rigorous and independent point of view. For a data professional, the opportunity to work within the Eionet frameworkâ€”translating raw monitoring data into the evidence base that literally steers the European Green Dealâ€”is the highest possible application of my skillset.
The Urgency of the Mission Second, on a personal level, I cannot think of a human challenge more pressing than the climate and biodiversity crisis. We saw in the State of the Environment Report (SOER) that while our frameworks are robust, far too few of our targets are currently on track for 2030. This reality doesnâ€™t discourage me; it focuses me. I want to be part of the â€˜course correction,â€™ using data to identify exactly where we are lagging and how we can accelerate progress toward climate neutrality.
The Scale of the Challenge Finally, I am genuinely excited by the sheer scale of the challenge. Moving from urban-scale projects to a pan-European monitoring mandate is a significant leap, but it is one I feel prepared for. I am at a stage in my career where I want to contribute at the highest level possible. I am confident that my experience in harmonizing fragmented data across borders and my focus on health outcomes can provide the Agency with the â€˜connective tissueâ€™ needed to turn complex monitoring into actionable policy insights.




I view stress not as an individual burden to be hidden, but as a signal to recalibrate our collective focus. My approach to high-pressure situationsâ€”such as a tight reporting deadline for a major EEA indicatorâ€”is built on three pillars:

Above all, I am a team player. When pressure mounts, I believe in absolute transparency with my peers. I donâ€™t â€˜hideâ€™ from the stress; I bring it to the table so we can address it together. By fostering a supportive environment early on, I ensure that when a crisis hits, the team feels comfortable speaking up about bottlenecks before they become failures.
(â€˜Project Firstâ€™ Mindset) My first instinct in a stressed scenario is to shift the focus from individual tasks to the overall project objective. title: Course Guide
text:
Content
This course introduces students to the concepts, technologies, governance models, and socio-spatial implications of Smart Cities. It critically examines how digital technologies, data, and urban analytics are applied to address urban challenges such as sustainability, mobility, climate adaptation, inclusion and quality of life. Through a project-based approach, students work in groups to analyse a real or simulated urban case, develop a Smart Cities solution, and reflect on ethical, social and governance dimensions. In this course, the student will gain fundamental theoretical and practical knowledge to understand smart cities, including the relationship to the sustainability debate applies knowledge and skills to a real-life case study involving local communities in the indicator analysis, development of Smart City planning solutions and policy recommendations for the built environment. Be able to critically reflect on Smart City concepts and communicate the results of Smart City strategies to stakeholders. This course utilises acquired knowledge from previous and parallel running courses, such as the advanced methods course, ethics in research, data analysis in GIS, and urban policies, and adds to it the component of smart sustainable cities and the human factor.

title: Systems Thinking
text:
1. The Spatial Dimension

The Logic of â€œWhereâ€: Focuses on geometry, distance, and density.
Key Question: How does the physical arrangement of assets (buildings, parks, roads) determine urban performance?
Core Concept: Social Physics. Just like gravity, â€œmassâ€ (high-density jobs or housing) exerts a pull on the surrounding area.

title: Systems Thinking
text:
2. The Relational Dimension

The Logic of â€œConnectionâ€: Focuses on topology and network hierarchy.
Key Question: How is the city â€œwiredâ€? Is it about how far you are in meters, or how many turns you are from the main network?
Core Concept: Graph Theory. The city as nodes and edges.

title: Systems Thinking
text:
3. The Temporal Dimension

The Logic of â€œWhenâ€: Focuses on change, evolution, and path dependency.
Key Question: How did the city get here, and how fast is it changing?
Core Concept: Dynamics. Recognizing that an urban intervention today might take 10 years to show its true impact (delays).

title: Systems Thinking
text:
4. The Systemic Dimension

The Logic of â€œWhyâ€: Focuses on causality and interdependencies.
Key Question: What are the unintended consequences? If we improve transport, does it inadvertently raise rents and displace the people it was meant to help?
Core Concept: Feedback Loops. Circular causality where an output of a system becomes an input for the next cycle.

title: Systems Thinking
text:
Land-Use Transport

eg. Predicting the impact of a new Metro line on residential density in a suburban area.



Pros
Excellent for long-term strategic planning and infrastructure â€œstress testing.â€

Cons
Highly aggregate (treats people as masses) and mostly static (ignores the â€œchaosâ€ of daily life).





What it lacks


Temporal and Systemic feedback. It assumes a city is a puzzle that can be â€œsolvedâ€ into a perfect balance.

title: Systems Thinking
text:
Network Models

eg. Redesigning a town center to increase footfall for local shops by improving topological connectivity.



Pros
Very high correlation with real-world human movement; requires minimal data (just the map).

Cons
Can be â€œblindâ€ to land use. It might predict high movement on a street that is topologically central but has no reason for people to go there.





What it lacks


Systemic â€œAttractors.â€ It prioritizes the shape of the container over the content inside it.

text:

title: Systems Thinking
text:
System Dynamics

eg. Modeling how a city-wide â€œAir Quality Zoneâ€ affects car ownership and public health over two decades.



Pros
Powerful for identifying â€œPolicy Resistanceâ€ and understanding long-term, non-linear consequences.

Cons
â€œSpatially Blindâ€â€”it treats the entire city (or zone) as a single bucket, ignoring internal geography.





What it lacks


Spatial Granularity. It assumes a city is a â€œwell-mixedâ€ vat of variables rather than a physical place with unique neighborhoods.

title: Systems Thinking
text:
Agent-Based Models
ABM & Celullar Automata (CA)




Primary Dimensions:


Spatial (High) + Systemic (High) + Temporal (Medium).






The Anatomy

Agents: (People, vehicles, firms) with unique attributes.
Rules: Simple â€œIf/Thenâ€ behaviors.
Environment: The grid or network they inhabit.


The Engine
Bottom-up Micro-simulation. Simple rules from the agents give rise to â€œemergentâ€ states from thousands of these local interactions.

title: Systems Thinking
text:
Agent-Based Models

_eg. Simulating pedestrian evacuation patterns in a high-density transit hub to identify â€œbottlenecksâ€ that traditional flow models miss.



Pros
Captures â€œEmergent Phenomenaâ€ and diversity; allows for the modeling of irrational or â€œhumanâ€ behaviors.

Cons
Computationally expensive; very difficult to â€œvalidateâ€ because small changes in rules can lead to wildly different outcomes.





What it lacks


Predictive Certainty. Because it is stochastic (probabilistic), it gives you a range of â€œpossible futuresâ€ rather than a single definitive answer.

title: Systems Thinking
text:
The â€œWickedâ€ Problem

Urban challenges are not puzzles (with one right answer).
They are Wicked Problems:

They are interconnected: solving one creates another.
They have no â€œstopping ruleâ€ or perfect solution.
They are better or worse, not right or wrong.


Key Characteristics of Wicked Problems:

No definitive formulation: The problem itself is hard to define.
No â€œstopping ruleâ€: Thereâ€™s no clear point at which you know itâ€™s solved.
Solutions arenâ€™t true/false: They are only â€œgoodâ€ or â€œbad,â€ not objectively correct.
Irreversible consequences: Every attempt to solve it has lasting impacts, making â€œtrials countâ€.
Interconnectedness: Solving one part often creates or reveals other problems. :::

title: Systems Thinking
text:
System Archetypes

Balancing & LimitsUnintended FeedbackResource & Power Loops



Limits to Growth: A tech-hub grows fast until housing prices drive out the talent, hitting a plateau.
Eroding Goals: Reducing environmental targets because the current infrastructure â€œcannot handleâ€ the cost of meeting them.
Growth and Underinvestment: Demand for public transit grows, but the city delays purchasing new trains, leading to a collapse in service quality.




Fixes that Fail: Widening a road to fix traffic leads to â€œinduced demand,â€ creating more traffic than before.
Shifting the Burden: Using temporary â€œband-aidâ€ repairs on aging water pipes instead of replacing the fundamental infrastructure.
Escalation: Two neighboring districts compete to offer the lowest taxes to attract firms, eventually bankrupting their own public services.




Tragedy of the Commons: Unregulated groundwater extraction by individual buildings leading to the sinking of the entire cityâ€™s foundation.
Success to the Successful: High-income neighborhoods receive the best schools, which increases property values and further concentrates educational funding there.
Accidental Adversaries: A transit agency and a housing department both try to optimize their own KPIs, but end up blocking each otherâ€™s long-term goals.

Connect & Loop: Draw the arrows. Is the relationship (+) or (-)?
Find the Archetype: Can you spot a â€œFix that Failâ€ or â€œLimits to Growthâ€?

Validation: We are mapping theories, not yet proving them.

title: Data Visualisation Principles
text:
Data visualisation plays a crucial role in modern decision-making by transforming complex datasets into accessible visual narratives. In an era where data-driven decisions shape industries, effective visualisations help stakeholders quickly grasp insights and patterns, leading to informed and strategic choices.By turning abstract numbers into visual stories, data visualisation enhances understanding, fosters communication, and drives impactful actions.






Tip



In this session we will mostly focus on non-spatial visualisation, but many of the principles also apply to the times when you will be creating maps to be part of your stories.




The main purposes of enhancing your narrative with data can be categorised into three key areas:

Facilitating quick understanding of complex information.
Identifying patterns, trends, and outliers.
Guiding decision-makers towards strategic actions aligned with your objectives.

title: Data Visualisation Principles
text:
Tools and Technologies
Selecting the right tool for the job involves considering several factors, including how you plan to share the visualisations, the need for ongoing maintenance, and your own level of expertise. If the data is likely to change frequently, choosing a tool that supports dynamic updates or easy revisions is crucial. Additionally, the way you share your visualisationsâ€”whether through static reports, interactive dashboards, or embedded in web pagesâ€”will influence the tool selection. Finally, your own proficiency and familiarity with the tool should be taken into account to ensure efficiency and effectiveness in creating impactful visualisations.

title: Data Visualisation Principles
text:
Exploring vs.Â Presenting

â€œDonâ€™t run before you can walkâ€

Start simple and gradually build complexity. In data visualisation, itâ€™s tempting to jump straight to advanced tools or sophisticated designs, but this can lead to confusion and inefficiency if the basics are not well understood. Begin with simple exploratory analyses to understand your data, then progressively refine and enhance your visualisations as your message becomes clearer and your narrative more defined.


Exploratory data visualisation
is about discovering insights, identifying patterns, and asking new questions. It is most useful during the initial stages of data analysis when the goal is to understand the data and its structure. At this stage, itâ€™s not about perfection but about exploration and iteration.



Explanatory data visualisation
on the other hand, is about communicating a specific message or insight clearly to an audience. It involves polishing the visualisation, ensuring accuracy, and crafting a narrative that guides the viewer to the intended conclusion.


Learning when to switch from exploration to presentation is key to managing efforts effectively. Investing time in refining and polishing a visualisation is only worthwhile once the message is clear and impactful.

title: Data Visualisation Principles
text:
Principles of Data Visualisation

Gestalt Principles
The Gestalt principles originate from a psychological theory developed by German psychologists in the early 20th century. These principles explain how humans naturally perceive visual elements as organized patterns or wholes, rather than as separate components (see Wagemans 2012). In data visualisation, Gestalt principles help designers arrange information in a way that is easily understood and visually appealing. By leveraging these principles, data visualisations can guide viewers to see relationships, hierarchies, and narratives within the data more intuitively.








Principle
Description
Example




Proximity
Elements that are close to each other are perceived as a group.



Similarity
Items that share visual characteristics are seen as related.



Continuity
The eye follows lines and curves smoothly without abrupt changes.



Closure
Incomplete shapes are perceived as complete wholes.



Connectedness
Items connected by lines or other visual cues are seen as related.



Colour
Utilises hues and shades to convey meaning and hierarchy.



White Space
Strategic use of empty space to enhance readability and focus.




These (and many other) principles guide visual perception and interpretation by leveraging the brainâ€™s natural tendencies to group similar elements, follow continuous lines, and fill in gaps to perceive complete shapes. By applying these principles, designers can direct the viewerâ€™s attention, create visual hierarchies, and improve the overall user experience. This strategic arrangement of visual elements not only enhances comprehension but also makes complex data more approachable and meaningful.


Choosing the Right Chart
Matching data types to the most effective visualisation is essential for conveying the intended message clearly and accurately. Different types of dataâ€”such as categorical, numerical, and temporal dataâ€”require different visualisation approaches to effectively highlight patterns, trends, and relationships.

Categorical data, which represents discrete groups or categories, is best displayed using bar charts, pie charts, or stacked column charts for comparing proportions or frequencies.
Numerical data, especially when showing distributions or relationships, is effectively visualised through histograms, scatter plots, or line graphs.
Temporal data, which involves time series or sequences, is well-suited to line charts or area charts to show trends over time.

Selecting the right chart type enhances the narrative and helps the audience interpret the data more intuitively.

NYTimes Chart Doctor Poster








TipAim forâ€¦




Clarity and simplicity: Avoid clutter and focus on the message.
Accuracy and integrity: Represent data truthfully.
Aesthetics and engagement: Use colors, fonts, and layouts strategically.









WarningCommon Pitfalls




Misleading graphs (e.g., truncated axes, improper scaling).
Overcomplicating with too much information.
Choosing the wrong type of visualisation for the data.

As the field continues to evolve, it is crucial to stay curious and experiment with new tools and techniques. Exploring different visualisation methods can inspire creativity and enhance your storytelling abilities.
